choices.text: Stewart Treves syndrome
Breast cancer metastasis

questions.text: A patient with long-standing lymphedema post modified radical mastectomy (MRM) 2 years ago presented with acute worsening of the lymphedema and the following finding on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stewart Treves syndrome

 

Option B:

 

Stewart Treves syndrome is lymphangiosarcoma that develops in long standing cases of lymphedema post axillary lymph node dissection and irradiation for breast cancer.

 

It presents as acute worsening of lymphedema and appearance of bluish-red skin and multiple subcutaneous nodules which can ulcerate and cause hemorrhage.

 

Treatment - pre op chemotherapy and radiation followed by surgical excision, often radical amputation.

 

Prognosis is poor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Cellulitis. Incorrect. While cellulitis can occur in patients with lymphedema, the acute worsening of lymphedema with the appearance of bluish-red skin and multiple subcutaneous nodules, as described in the scenario, is not characteristic of cellulitis.

 

Option C: Breast cancer metastasis. Incorrect. While breast cancer metastasis is a possibility, the presentation described is more suggestive of Stewart Treves syndrome, which is a specific complication of lymphedema in breast cancer patients.

 

Option D: Seroma formation is an immediate post operative complication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stewart Treves syndrome, is a rare complication of long-standing lymphedema in breast cancer patients, characterized by the development of lymphangiosarcoma in the affected limb.

 

Ref: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 20th Edition Page 1855.

questions.text: Identify the mismatch type of surgical wound?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clean-contaminated- Breast abscess

 

Option B:

 

Pus in wound is a dirty wound.

 

Class II Clean:  Uninfected operative wounds, no inflammation is encountered. Respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Primarily closed and, if necessary, drained using a closed system

 

Class III Clean contaminated: Respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tracts are entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination. No evidence of infection or major break in technique is encountered.

 

Class IIII Contaminated: Open, fresh accidental wounds. Operation in which there is major breaks in sterile technique (e.g., open cardiac massage) or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract. Incisions in which acute, non-purulent inflammation is encountered.

 

Class IVI Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalised tissue, and those that involve existing clinical infection (pus) or perforated viscera.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Breast abscess contains pus. Pus in wound is a dirty wound and not clean- contaminated.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 28.

questions.text: Image of a patient with large ulcerated breast cancer with liver metastasis. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Simple mastectomy

 

The patient in the image has a large ulcerated breast tumor with confirmed liver metastasis, classifying the cancer as stage IV (T4, M1). In cases of stage IV breast cancer with distant metastasis, the primary goal of management shifts from curative to palliative care, focusing on improving quality of life and managing symptoms.

For patients with large ulcerated tumors, palliative simple mastectomy may be considered to alleviate symptoms like pain, ulceration, discharge, or infection, which can significantly impact the patient’s quality of life. This procedure is not intended to cure but to provide local control of the tumor and improve comfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRM (Modified Radical Mastectomy): This is a more aggressive surgical approach that involves removal of the breast tissue along with axillary lymph nodes. It is typically reserved for curative intent in earlier stages of breast cancer without distant metastasis. It is not appropriate for palliation in stage IV disease with liver metastasis.

 

Option C. Radical mastectomy: This involves removal of the entire breast, underlying chest muscles, and axillary lymph nodes. This extensive procedure is rarely performed today and is not suitable for palliative care in metastatic disease due to its high morbidity without a survival benefit.

 

Option D. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is used in locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) to shrink tumors before surgery, but in the presence of distant metastasis (M1), systemic chemotherapy alone would be preferred for palliative purposes. Surgery would only follow if there was a significant symptomatic tumor burden requiring local control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with stage IV breast cancer with distant metastasis, such as liver metastasis, the primary focus is on palliation. Simple mastectomy may be performed to manage symptoms from a large ulcerated tumor, but more extensive surgeries or curative approaches are not indicated.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman underwent a modified radical mastectomy for breast cancer. A few days after the surgery, she presents with swelling and a fluid collection beneath the skin flaps in her axillary region. Which of the following is the most common complication following mastectomy surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seroma

 

  • A seroma is the accumulation of fluid beneath the skin flaps after surgery, particularly in the axilla following mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection.
  • It is the most common complication of mastectomy, occurring in approximately 30% of cases.
  • Seromas can lead to discomfort, delayed wound healing, and an increased risk of infection if not adequately drained.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymphoedema: Lymphoedema is swelling that occurs due to the disruption of lymphatic drainage, which can happen after axillary lymph node dissection. While it is a well-known complication of mastectomy, it is less common than seroma formation in the immediate postoperative period.

 

Option C. Wound infection: Wound infections can occur after any surgical procedure, including mastectomy. However, the incidence of seroma formation is higher than that of wound infections.

 

Option D. Intercostobrachial nerve injury: Injury to the intercostobrachial nerve, leading to numbness or paresthesia in the upper arm, is a recognized complication of mastectomy, but it is less common compared to seroma formation.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Seroma is the most common complication following mastectomy, occurring in approximately 30% of cases and requires management to prevent infection and promote healing.

questions.text: Lymph from a cancerous breast primarily drains into which of the following nodes? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Anterior (pectoral) nodes

 

Explanation: 

 

The lymphatic drainage of the breast primarily flows into the anterior (pectoral) group of axillary lymph nodes. These nodes are positioned along the lateral thoracic vessels at the lower border of the pectoralis minor muscle. Approximately 75% of the lymph from the breast tissue drains into the axillary nodes, with the anterior group receiving the major portion. This makes the anterior (pectoral) nodes the first-line lymph nodes to receive drainage from cancerous breast tissue, particularly from the upper lateral quadrant where breast cancer most commonly occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Apical nodes: Located at the apex of the axilla, these nodes receive lymph secondarily after it has passed through other axillary node groups. They're not the primary recipients of breast lymph drainage.
  • Option C. Parasternal (internal thoracic) nodes: These nodes receive about 20% of breast lymphatic drainage, primarily from the medial quadrants of the breast, but are not the main drainage pathway.
  • Option D. Supraclavicular nodes: These become involved primarily in advanced cases of breast cancer. They receive lymph only after it has passed through multiple other node groups.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Anterior (pectoral) lymph nodes are the primary recipients of lymphatic drainage from the breast, making them crucial for early detection and staging of breast malignancy.

questions.text:
Match the following staging/grading systems with their respective cancers: 

 

Staging Systems:

  1. Gleason grading
  2. Duke staging
  3. Robson staging
  4. Bloom-Richardson grading

 

Cancers:

  1. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC)
  2. Prostate cancer
  3. Colorectal carcinoma
  4. Breast cancer
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-1, D-4

 

A. Gleason staging – 2. Prostate cancer: This system is used to grade prostate cancer based on histological patterns.

 

B. Duke staging – 3. Colorectal carcinoma: Duke staging is a classic system used to classify colorectal cancer based on the depth of invasion and lymph node involvement.

 

C. Robson staging – 1. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC): Robson's system is a staging classification for RCC based on tumor extent and spread.

 

D. Bloom-Richardson grading – 4. Breast cancer: This system is used to grade breast carcinoma based on histological characteristics such as mitotic count, nuclear grade, and tubule formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Different cancers have unique staging and grading systems tailored to their anatomical and pathological characteristics. Familiarity with these systems is essential for diagnosis, treatment planning, and prognosis.

questions.text: Locally advanced breast cancer can be defined as all except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumor more than 4 cm

 

While a tumor size larger than 4 cm is indicative of a relatively large tumor, it alone does not define locally advanced breast cancer. Locally advanced breast cancer typically involves not only tumor size but also the extent of its spread to nearby structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inflammatory breast cancer: Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive subtype of breast cancer characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth in the breast. It is considered an advanced stage of breast cancer.

 

Option C. Chest wall involvement: Locally advanced breast cancer is often defined by its involvement of the chest wall. This means that the cancer has spread beyond the breast tissue and may affect the underlying muscles and structures of the chest wall.

 

Option D. Skin involvement: Skin involvement, such as changes in the appearance of the skin over the breast like peau’d orange or ulceration, can be a feature of locally advanced breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor more than 5 cm, not 4 is classified as LABC.

 

Locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) includes: (Mnemonic – CUBE N2)

 

C - Chest wall invasion

 

U - Ulceration of skin

 

B - Both (chest wall invasion and ulceration of skin)

 

E - E(I)nflammatory carcinoma

 

N2 - fixed axillary lymph nodes

questions.text: Mrs. Patel is a 45-year-old woman who has recently been diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Her doctor informs her that the cancer is hormone-dependent. The doctor recommends a treatment plan that includes surgery, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy. What is the drug used for estrogen dependent breast cancer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used to treat hormone receptor-positive breast cancers, particularly in premenopausal women. It is effective for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer, which is hormone-dependent. Tamoxifen works by blocking the effects of estrogen in the breast tissue, thereby preventing cancer cells from growing and spreading.

  • Mechanism of Action: Tamoxifen competes with estrogen for binding to estrogen receptors in breast tissue. By blocking estrogen's effects, it inhibits the growth and proliferation of estrogen-dependent cancer cells.
  • Administration: Tamoxifen is taken orally, usually once a day for five years.
  • Side Effects: Common side effects include hot flashes, mood changes, vaginal dryness, and an increased risk of blood clots (DVT).

 

Uses of Tamoxifen:

  • Primary Prophylaxis: Used for the primary prophylaxis of breast cancer in high-risk women.
  • Risk Reduction: Reduces the risk of carcinoma in the contralateral breast.
  • Recurrence Prevention: Lowers the risk of recurrence of carcinoma in both ipsilateral and contralateral breasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrogen: Estrogen is not used as a treatment for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer because it would promote cancer cell growth. In fact, therapies aim to reduce or block estrogen to prevent cancer progression.

 

Option B. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene citrate is a medication used to induce ovulation in women with fertility issues. It is not used in the treatment of breast cancer.

 

Option D. Adriamycin (Doxorubicin): Adriamycin is a chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancer, including breast cancer. It works by interfering with the DNA in cancer cells, preventing them from dividing and growing. While effective in some cancer treatments, it is not specifically used for hormone therapy in estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen is the drug used for treating estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer by blocking the effects of estrogen on breast tissue, thereby preventing the growth and spread of hormone-dependent cancer cells.

choices.text: Located on the long arm of chromosome 13

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a family history of breast cancer is found to have a BRCA1 mutation. Which of the following characteristics is associated with a BRCA1 mutation compared to a BRCA2 mutation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Associated with medullary carcinoma

 

  • BRCA1 mutations are located on the long arm of chromosome 17 and are associated with poorly differentiated tumors and a triple-negative hormone receptor status (ER/PR-negative, HER2-negative).
  • They are also linked to medullary carcinoma. BRCA2 mutations are located on chromosome 13.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Located on the long arm of chromosome 13: BRCA2 mutations are located on chromosome 13.

 

Option B. Well-differentiated tumors: BRCA1 mutations are associated with poorly-differentiated tumors.

 

Option C. ER/PR-positive hormone receptor status: BRCA1 mutations are ER/PR negative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • BRCA1 mutations are linked to chromosome 17, poorly differentiated tumors, triple-negative status, and medullary carcinoma, while BRCA2 mutations are linked to chromosome 13.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman undergoes a modified radical mastectomy (MRM) for breast cancer. During the surgery, the surgeon identifies and carefully preserves the nerve marked in the image. Which nerve is being identified in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Long thoracic nerve

 

  • This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle and is important for scapular protraction and stabilization.
  • Damage to the long thoracic nerve can result in a "winged scapula."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thoracodorsal nerve: The thoracodorsal nerve, also known as the nerve to latissimus dorsi, is responsible for innervating the latissimus dorsi muscle. This muscle plays a key role in shoulder adduction, extension, and internal rotation. The thoracodorsal nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and runs along the axillary region, which is commonly encountered and preserved during surgeries such as a modified radical mastectomy.

 

Option C. Spinal accessory nerve: This nerve innervates the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. It is often involved in shoulder elevation and neck movements.

 

Option D. Dorsal scapular nerve: This nerve innervates the rhomboid muscles and the levator scapulae, which are involved in the retraction and elevation of the scapula.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle and is important for scapular protraction and stabilization.
  • Damage to the long thoracic nerve can result in a "winged scapula."

choices.text: Early age of first live childbirth
Early menarche

questions.text: Which out of these is not a risk factor for breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early age of first live child birth.

 

Option B:

 

Early age of first live childbirth an early age at first full-term pregnancy is generally considered a protective factor against breast cancer. This protection may be due to hormonal changes that occur during pregnancy that have a long-term effect on the cells in the breast. Having the first child after 35 years of age (late parity) is a risk factor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Alcohol. Alcohol consumption is a well-established risk factor for the development of breast cancer. The risk increases with the amount of alcohol consumed, and this association is thought to be due to alcohol's effects on estrogen and other hormonal levels, as well as its ability to damage DNA in cells.

 

Option C: Early menarche. Early onset of menstruation (menarche) is a risk factor for breast cancer. The earlier a woman begins menstruating, the longer her breast tissue is exposed to estrogen, which can promote the growth of cancer cells.

 

Option D: Nulliparity. Nulliparity, or never having given birth to a child, is also a recognized risk factor for breast cancer. This is thought to be due to the absence of the protective hormonal changes that occur during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Protective factors for carcinoma breast:

 

  • Early age at first pregnancy
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Oophorectomy
  • Exercise
  • Tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors

 

Risk factors for breast carcinoma:

 

  • Age: incidence increases with increasing age.
  • Sex: more common in females.
  • Personal history and family history of breast cancer
  • Race, ethnicity (white women have increased risk compared to women of other races)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Mammographically dense breast
  • Genetic factors:
  • Mutations in tumor suppressor genes
    • BRCA 1
    • BRCA 2
    • TP53
    • CHEK2
  • Hereditary syndromes
    • Li Fraumeni syndrome
    • Cowden’s syndrome
    • HNPCC syndrome
    • Peutz - Jeghers syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Hormonal factors (hypercarotenemia is the risk factor)
    • Early menarche (<12 years)
    • Late gmenopause (> 55 years)
    • First full-term pregnancy >35 years
    • Nulliparity
    • Obesity (Postmenopausal)
    • Higher socioeconomic status, high fat diet, alcohol intake, chest wall radiation
  • OCPills and smoking have a low risk association

 

Ref: Bailey & love’s short practice of surgery -28th edition page no 931, table 58.3

choices.text: Apocrine metaplasia
Florid hyperplasia
Atypical hyperplasia

questions.text: Which of the following is not a pre malignant lesion associated with breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Apocrine metaplasia

 

Option A:

 

Apocrine metaplasia is seen in breast cysts and is always benign.

 

Apocrine Metaplasia is a benign change in the breast where ductal epithelial cells transform into cells resembling those of the apocrine glands. It is often found in fibrocystic changes and is not associated with an increased risk of developing breast cancer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Florid Hyperplasia Florid hyperplasia, also known as usual ductal hyperplasia, is an overgrowth of the cells lining the ducts of the breast tissue. While it is not in itself considered premalignant, there is a slight increase in the risk of developing breast cancer compared to the general population, particularly when the hyperplasia is moderate to florid.

 

Option C: Atypical Hyperplasia Atypical hyperplasia is a condition where there is an overgrowth of cells in the breast with some atypical (abnormal) appearance. This includes both atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) and atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH). It is a recognized premalignant lesion and is associated with a higher risk of developing breast cancer — approximately four to five times the risk compared to women without these lesions.

 

Option D: LCIS Lobular Carcinoma in Situ (LCIS) is a condition in which abnormal cells are found in the lobules of the breast. This is considered a marker for an increased risk of developing breast cancer in either breast and is therefore often categorized as a premalignant lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apocrine metaplasia (Option A) is not a premalignant lesion associated with breast cancer; it is a benign finding commonly seen in breast cysts and does not confer an increased risk for developing breast cancer. Conversely, conditions like florid hyperplasia, atypical hyperplasia, and LCIS are associated with a higher risk and are considered premalignant to varying degrees.

 

No increased risk

 

  • Adenosis, sclerosing or florid
  • Apocrine metaplasia
  • Cysts, macro and / or micro
  • Duct ectasia
  • Fibroadenoma
  • Fibrosis
  • Hyperplasia
  • Mastitis (inflammation)
  • Periductal mastitis

 

Slightly increased risk (1.5-2 times)

 

  • Hyperplasia, moderate or florid, solid, or papillary
  • Papilloma with a fibrovascular core (relative risk =3)

 

Moderately increased risk (5 times)

 

  • Atypical hyperplasia (ductal or lobular) (Relative risk = 4 or 5)

 

Insufficient data to assign a risk

 

  • Solitary papilloma of lactiferous sinus
  • Radial scar lesion

 

 

Ref: Bailey & love’s short practice of surgery -27th edition page no 871

28th Ed. Table 58.3

choices.text: BRCA1 is associated with 50 to 85% lifetime risk of Ca Breast.
BRCA2 is located in chromosome 13.
BRCA1 is mostly associated with triple receptor-negative cancers.
BRCA1 is highly associated with male breast carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about BRCA genes is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BRCA1 is highly associated with male breast carcinoma.

 

Option D:

 

BRCA1 is highly associated with male breast carcinoma. This statement is not correct. While mutations in both BRCA1 and BRCA2 can increase the risk of male breast cancer, BRCA2 mutations are more commonly associated with breast cancer in men than BRCA1 mutations.

 

Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

 

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes with Autosomal dominant inheritance.

 

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric inherited form compared to sporadic cases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: BRCA1 is associated with a 50 to 85% lifetime risk of Ca Breast. This statement is correct. Women with mutations in the BRCA1 gene have a significantly increased risk of developing breast cancer, with lifetime risks ranging from 50% to 85%.

 

Option B: BRCA2 is located on chromosome 13. This statement is correct. The BRCA2 gene is indeed located on chromosome 13q.

 

Option C: BRCA1 is mostly associated with triple receptor-negative cancers. This statement is correct. BRCA1 mutations are often associated with breast cancers that are triple-negative, meaning they lack estrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, and HER2/neu expression.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: Schwartz’s principle of surgery-10th edition page no 515

Devita-cancer principle and practice of oncology; 10th edition page no 1109

choices.text: Infiltration of Cooper’s ligaments
Obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics
Infiltration of lactiferous duct
Infiltration of subcutaneous veins

questions.text: A woman presents with rapidly progressive breast lump with skin changes as shown. What is the likely pathology responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics

 

Option B:

 

The characteristic Peau d'orange appearance in breast carcinoma is due to specific pathological changes associated with dermal subcutaneous lymphatics obstruction, typically by cancer cells, leading to lymphatic edema. This edema causes the skin to take on a texture reminiscent of an orange peel, with enlarged pores and thickened skin

 

Explanation:

 

Option C: Infiltration of Lactiferous Duct While the infiltration of lactiferous ducts can lead to nipple retraction or inversion, it is not the cause of Peau d'orange. Nipple retraction occurs because the ducts shorten as they are invaded by cancer cells, which pulls the nipple inward.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peau d'orange in breast carcinoma is specifically caused by the obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics, leading to lymphatic edema and the characteristic orange peel-like texture of the skin, an indicator of advanced disease (T4b).

 

Peau D'orange is caused by cutaneous lymphatic edema due to the obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics. It is French for “orange skin”.

 

Other appearances due to local invasion are as follows:

 

  • Infiltration of single cooper's ligaments leads to dimpling of skin while multiple ligaments leads to puckering/wrinkling. Simple maneuvers such as stretching the arms high above the head or tensing the pectoralis muscles may accentuate asymmetries and dimpling.
  • Infiltration of the lactiferous ducts leads to nipple retraction. Note: an inverted nipple can be simply pulled out, however a retracted nipple cannot be pulled out.
  • Cancer-en-cuirasse: in this condition, the skin of the chest is infiltrated with carcinoma and its appearance has been compared to that of a coat. It occurs in local recurrence after mastectomy.

 

Note:

 

  • Peau D'orange indicates skin involvement (T4b) in breast carcinoma.
  • Dimpling of the skin and nipple retraction do not indicate skin involvement.

 

 

Ref: Bailey & love’s short practice of surgery -28th edition page 932, Schwartz’s principles of surgery- 10th edition page no 518, Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition page no 849

choices.text: MRM in node negative patients
MRM in node positive patients
BCT in node negative patients
BCT in node positive patients

questions.text: In which of the given cases is this procedure usually performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BCT in node negative patients

 

Option C:

 

The following image shows a sentinel lymph node biopsy using a gamma camera.

 

BCT in Node-Negative Patients Breast-conserving therapy (BCT) in node-negative patients is the typical indication for SLNB. The procedure is used to assess whether breast cancer has spread to the sentinel node, which is the first lymph node to which cancer cells are likely to spread from the primary tumor. If the sentinel node is free of cancer, it suggests that the other nodes are also likely to be cancer-free, potentially obviating the need for full axillary lymph node dissection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A and B: MRM: Axillary lymph node dissection is usually performed as part of the surgical treatment rather than SLNB in all cases of MRM.

 

Option D: BCT in Node-Positive Patients In node-positive patients, BCT would include an axillary lymph node dissection to address the known nodal involvement, rather than just an SLNB, because the presence of cancer cells in the lymph nodes is already confirmed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most commonly performed as part of breast-conserving therapy in patients with no clinical evidence of lymph node involvement (node-negative) to determine the presence of metastatic cancer cells in the sentinel lymph node.

 

Sentinel lymph node biopsy:

 

  • First performed by Dr. Cabana for penile carcinoma
  • Sentinel lymph node is the first draining lymph node
  • Only done on node-negative tumors as a part of BCS/BCT. In node positive patients, BCT includes axillary lymph node clearance directly (without SLNB).
  • In MRM, axillary clearance is done irrespective of clinical nodal status.
  • Technique: methylene blue dye or radioisotope (technetium)-labeled albumin is injected into breast tissue (or subdermal tissue) at the site of the primary tumor or at the subareolar position. The sentinel node is identified as a blue node or as a radioactive node (using a gamma camera).
  • The frozen section biopsy is sent to the pathologist for identification of cancer cells. If the biopsy is positive for cancer cells, then axillary dissection is simultaneously performed.
  • The combination of blue dye and technetium-labeled colloid has been reported to improve the detection of sentinel lymph nodes.
  • Newer techniques involve the use of a fluorescent or magnetic tracer instead of the radiolabeled dye.

 

Ref: Bailey & love’s practice of surgery -28th edition page no 936-37.

choices.text: T3
T4a
T4b

questions.text: A woman presents with a breast tumor of size 6 x 3cm, with adherence to the pectoralis major muscle. Overlying skin shows dimpling. As her surgeon, what will you designate her T staging as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T3

 

Explanation:

 

The tumor is of size 6cm. Hence it is stage T3 (>5cm). Fixity to pectoralis major doesn’t affect staging. Skin dimpling is not classified as T4b.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irrelevant to the size of the tumor, if the tumor shows extension to the chest wall or skin, it is classified as T4. However, there are two exceptions.

 

  • Invasion or adherence to pectoralis muscle in the absence of chest wall involvement does not qualify as T4.
  • Similarly, involvement of the dermis in the form of dimpling/puckering/retraction of nipple does not qualify as T4.

 

Points to Remember

 

  • In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6*3 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3(>5 cm).
  • Skin involvement does not include nipple retraction and skin dimpling.
  • Supraclavicular lymph node involvement indicates N3c.
  • Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.
  • If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump.
  • If lumps are present in both breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

 

TNM Staging of carcinoma breast.

 

 

 

#Chest wall includes serratus anterior, intercostal muscles, ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of the chest wall.

 

*Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IIIB) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peau d'orange) involving ≥ 1/3rd of breast.

 

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

 

Ref: Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition page no 843 and 844, Schwartz’s principle of surgery -10th edition page no 532, Journal AJCC-2017, Pg 674.

choices.text: T2 N2a M0
T4b N3c M0
T2 N3c M1
T4b N3c M1

questions.text: A patient present with a left breast lump of size 3cm x 4cm. The overlying skin has a ‘orange-like skin’ appearance. On the right side, mobile axillary nodes are palpable. On the left side, supraclavicular lymph nodes are palpable. The most appropriate tumor staging is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T4b N3c M1

 

Explanation:

 

In the TNM staging system for breast cancer, T refers to the size and extent of the main tumor, N describes the absence or presence and extent of regional lymph node involvement, and M indicates the absence or presence of distant metastases.

 

  • Tumor of any size with overlying skin involvement (Peau d'orange appearance): T4b
  • Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph node involvement: N3c
  • Involvement of any contralateral lymph nodes indicates metastasis in the case of breast carcinoma: M1
  • Therefore, the staging is T4b N3c M1.

choices.text: Luminal A: ER/PR +, Her 2 -, Ki67 high
Luminal B: ER +, Her 2 -, Ki 67 high
Triple negative: ER/PR -, Her 2 -, Ki 67 high
Her 2 enriched: ER/PR -, Her 2 +, Ki 67 high

questions.text: Identify the mismatch receptor profile of breast cancer:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Luminal A: ER/PR +, Her 2 -, Ki67 high

 

Option A:

 

Luminal A: ER/PR +, Her 2 -, Ki67 high Luminal A breast cancers are typically ER and/or PR positive, HER2 negative, and have a low Ki-67 index, which indicates a lower rate of cell proliferation. This subtype generally has a better prognosis and is more responsive to hormonal therapy. Therefore, the presence of a high Ki-67 labeling index in this option is mismatched with the typical profile of Luminal A.

 

The molecular subtypes of breast cancer are characterized based on the presence or absence of hormone receptors (estrogen and progesterone receptors) and HER2 status, as well as proliferation rates, typically indicated by Ki-67 labeling index. Let's go through each

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Luminal B: ER +, Her 2 -, Ki 67 high. Luminal B cancers are ER-positive and tend to have a higher Ki-67 index than Luminal A, indicating a higher proliferation rate. They can be HER2 negative. This option is a correct match for the Luminal B subtype.

 

Option C: Triple Negative: ER, PR -, Her 2 -, Ki 67 high. Triple-negative breast cancers lack ER, PR, and HER2 expression. They often have a higher Ki-67 index, which is consistent with their more aggressive behavior. This option correctly describes the Triple Negative subtype.

 

Option D: Her 2 enriched: ER/PR -, Her 2 +, Ki 67 high. HER2-enriched cancers are characterized by the absence of hormone receptors (ER and PR negative) and overexpression/amplification of HER2. They often exhibit high Ki-67 levels, which correlates with the aggressive nature of this subtype. This option correctly represents the HER2-enriched subtype.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Luminal A breast cancers are typically ER/PR positive, HER2 negative, and have a low Ki-67 index, indicating lower proliferation rates. The presence of a high Ki-67 index in this subtype, as indicated in Option A, is a mismatch.

 

Along with ER, PR, and Her-2, a proliferation index known as ki-67 index is also used. Ki 67 is a nuclear protein associated with cellular proliferation.

 

Molecular classification of cancers:

 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 931, Table 58.4

questions.text: A patient with 3x2 cm nodular thyroid swelling underwent a thyroid profile. Normal T4 and TSH levels were seen. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. USG neck

USG is the next best step in the evaluation of a euthyroid patient with a solitary thyroid nodule. USG helps to classify the risk of the nodule into benign and malignant.

Benign nodules are easily compressible and can be seen to deform by applying pressure with the probe while performing USG. Malignant nodules tend to be hard and firm.

USG findings of a nodule that are considered suspicious of malignancy are:

  • Hypervascularity
  • Spiculations
  • Infiltrative margins
  • Hypoechoic compared to surrounding parenchyma

 

Reference: Bailey and Love: edition 27, page 808, 809

Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition, page 890

questions.text: A 27 year old female underwent an FNAC for a discrete thyroid swelling. The report showed a Thy2 lesion. What is your inference?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Non neoplastic lesion

FNAC reporting according to the Royal College of Pathologists UK:

Reference: Bailey and Love 27th edition, page 805

Sabiston textbook of surgery 2oth edition, page 898

questions.text: A radionuclide scan done in a patient with a thyroid nodular swelling, shows the following image. How much is the risk of this pathology being benign?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. 80%

The uptake by the thyroid of a low dose of either radiolabeled iodine (123I) or the cheaper technetium (99mTc) will demonstrate the distribution of activity in the whole gland.

Routine isotope scanning is unnecessary and inappropriate for distinguishing benign from malignant lesions because the majority (80%) of ‘cold’ swellings are benign and some (5%) functioning or ‘warm’ swellings will be malignant. Its principal value is in the toxic patient with a nodule or nodularity of the thyroid.

 

Reference: page 854 Bailey and Love edition 28th

choices.text: Sternal incision is always required to operate.
Most of the retrosternal goiters can be removed by neck incision
It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery
Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms

questions.text: Following options are a few statements about retrosternal goiter. Choose the correct statement.
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Most of the retrosternal goiters can be removed by neck incision

Most of the retrosternal goiters  can be removed by neck incision (transcervical.)

Option A: median sternotomy approach is indicated in:

  • Primary mediastinal goitre
  • Malignant retrosternal goitre
  • Very large retrosternal goiter
  • Recurrence in mediastinum for a primary mediastinal goitre whose boundaries or completely within the chest, resection is often achieved through a median sternotomy or thoracotomy to ensure that the vessels supplying the tumour are properly ligated. Removing the tumour through a cervical approach can result in uncontrolled bleeding and is generally avoided.

Option C: blood supply to retrosternal goitre is from the thyroid vessel.

Option D: surgical removal of the retrosternal goiter is indicated in patients with significant airway compression, in young patients who have symptoms such as dyspnea or dysphagia.

 

Reference: Bailey and Love 27th edition, pages 810,811

choices.text: A 24 year old woman with FNAC report of Bethesda category 4
A 60 year old man with FNAC report of Thy2
A 15 year old with recurrence of thyroid cyst
A 66 year old man with positive Pemberton’s sign

questions.text: Patients present in your OPD, with the following reports. To which patient will you least likely advise surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. A 60 year old man with FNAC report of Thy2

FNAC report Thy2 is suggestive of non neoplastic origin and is not an indication for surgery.

Indications for surgical management of thyroid swellings are in the following:

  • Neoplasia: FNAC positive Thy3-5 and clinical suspicion
  • Age
  • Male sex
  • Hard texture
  • Fixity
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
  • Recurrent cyst
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Pressure symptoms
  • Cosmesis
  • Patient’s wishes

 

Reference: bailey and love 27th edition, page 810

choices.text: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.text: Most usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy is?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Inadequate patient preparation

The usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy is inadequate patient preparation, before surgery. Patient preparation of operatively involves ensuring a euthyroid state.

Thyroid storm/ thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. The precipitating factors include;

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy.
  • Abrupt cessation of anti thyroid medications
  • Stress like
  • Infections
  • Thyroid or non thyroid surgery
  • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
  • Amiodarone administration
  • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
  • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mental state ( delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms: nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea

Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure: most common cause of death.

 

Reference: bailey and love 27th edition page 815

Schwartz’s principles of surgery 10th edition, page 1534

choices.text: Partial resection of each lobe removing the bulk of the gland
Total resection of lobes on one side, with partial resection of the other side
Total resection of one lobe with partial resection of three lobes
Resection of two lobe with the removal of isthmus

questions.text: The following statement best describes Hartley-Dunhill procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Total resection of lobes on one side, with partial resection of the other side

The Hartley Dunhill procedure involves total lobectomy on the affected side with subtotal resection of the less affected side.

Other thyroid surgeries:

  • Lobectomy: all or one thyroid lobe is removed
  • Hemithyroidectomy: total lobectomy of one lobe +isthmusectomy
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy: 2x subtotal lobectomy (leaving greater than 4g of thyroid tissue on each lobe) + isthmusectomy.
  • Near total thyroidectomy: total lobectomy but leaving less than 1g tissue adjacent to the RLN at the ligament of Berry on one lobe + isthmusectomy (Hartley-dunhill procedure)
  • Total thyroidectomy: 2x total lobectomy + isthmusectomy

 

Reference: Bailey and Love 27th edition, page 807

choices.text: In the TE groove as it forms one part of the Beahrs triangle
At the level of the Berry’s ligament as it enters the larynx
As the nerve loops around the aorta
Under the tubercle of Zuckerlandl on the posterolateral position of the gland

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a thyroid surgery. Which of the following points poses the highest risk for recurrent laryngeal nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. At the level of the Berry’s ligament as it enters the larynx

Berry's ligament is formed by posterior condensation of the pretracheal fascia and is attached to the larynx. It has the highest risk for RLN injury.

RLN is a branch of the vagus nerve. On the left, it recurs over the arch of aorta, and on the right over the subclavian artery.

Beahrs triangle also known as the recurrent laryngeal nerve triangle is formed by the:

  • Common carotid artery
  • Inferior thyroid arteries

Recurrent laryngeal nerve

Reference: Bailey and Love 27th edition, page 801

questions.text: A 30 year old female underwent a retro-esophageal goitre resection. She was found to have ptosis and loss of hemifacial sweating. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Horner’s syndrome

 

The cervical sympathetic trunk is at risk of injury in invasive thyroid cancers and retro-esophageal goiters and may result in Horner’s syndrome.

 

Reference: Schwartz’s principles of surgery 10th edition, page 1556

choices.text: Perform a re exploration of the thyroid gland
Call her for a bi annual follow up

questions.text: A 45 year old woman has come to your clinic for a follow up after she underwent a total thyroidectomy 2 months back, for papillary thyroid carcinoma. On doing a whole body iodine scan, the report suggested a positive iodine scan. How will you proceed further in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Radioactive iodine ablation

 

  • RAI ablation is undertaken when a whole body iodine scan is positive after a total thyroidectomy, for any differentiated thyroid cancer.
  • The presence of ang metastatic or residual thyroid tissue after total thyroidectomy can be detected by observing the uptake of RAI in the entire body. To achieve uptake of radioiodine, TSH levels need to be greatly increased.
  • A positive whole body thyroid scan after total thyroidectomy indicates that there is either a metastatic or residual disease present. These patients will be treated by RAI ablation.
  • A negative whole body iodine scan after total thyroidectomy indicates that there are no metastases or residual thyroid tissue present. These patients are followed up regularly with USG-neck, serum TG and TSH.

 

If the tumour is resistant to RAI, then EBRT(external beam radiotherapy) is done.

 

References: Bailey and Love: 27th edition, page 819

choices.text: In follicular carcinoma of thyroid, after total thyroidectomy

questions.text: Radioactive iodine ablation of thyroid is an absolute contraindication in?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Pregnant lady with papillary thyroid cancer

 

It is contraindicated in pregnancy due to exposure of the fetus to radiation.

 

Therapeutic uses of RAI are:

 

  • In primary thyrotoxicosis after 45 years
  • In autonomous toxic nodule after 45 years, it is useful as remaining gland will still function adequately after RT
  • In follicular carcinoma of thyroid, after total thyroidectomy, if there are secondaries elsewhere in the body, as in bones or lungs, then I131 is given.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 862,870

questions.text: HPE was done on a 50 year old patient with a history of a diffuse enlargement of thyroid gland. Lab studies revealed low T3, T4, high TSH and the presence of anti TPO antibodies. The HPE showed enlarged cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Which of the following malignancies is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Thyroid lymphoma

The case is suggestive of hashimoto’s thyroiditis. Thyroid lymphomas are associated in long standing cases. These are usually non-hodgkin lymphomas often associated with long standing Hashimoto’s thyroiditis.

clinical features:

  1. Fatigue, 2. Weight gain, 3. Constipation, 4. Dry skin, 5. Hair loss, 6. Muscle and joint pain, 7. Depression, 8. Menstrual irregularities, 9. Enlarged thyroid gland.

Diagnosis:

Trucut biopsy preferred over FNAC since FNAC cannot characterize lymphomas.

Treatment:

R-CHOP regimen of chemotherapy is the first line of management. i.e., Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Hydroxydaunorubicin (Adriamycin), oncovin (vincristine), prednisolone.

Chemotherapy and radiotherapy are often sufficient. Total thyroidectomy can be done in recurrent cases.

 

Reference: Schwartz’s principles of surgery 10th edition page 1538

Bailey and Love 27th edition page 821

choices.text: Prophylactic neck dissection is done.
Calcium supplementation is given post op
Thyroxine is withheld after surgery

questions.text: A 35 year old patient came to the surgeon with a thyroid swelling for 1 year. O/E the patient appeared euthyroid. Lymphadenopathy was a significant finding. The swelling was 3.5cm in size and was firm and immobile. A biopsy of the swelling showed the following histopathological picture. Choose the incorrect statement regarding management and post-op care.
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Hemithyroidectomy is done

The above picture shows papillary formation with a fibrovascular stalk, characteristic orphan Anne nuclei and psammoma bodies, diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Though the tumour is less than 4 cm, there is lymphadenopathy and hence total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection should be done.

Calcium supplementation is usually prescribed routinely to all patients after thyroidectomy to prevent symptoms of hypocalcemia.

Patients who are scheduled to receive RAI within 2-3 weeks of surgery may be discharged home without any thyroid hormone replacement. Thyroid hormone withdrawal raises the TSH level which stimulates radio iodine uptake and improves the efficacy of RAI.

Papillary thyroid cancer:

  • Most common thyroid cancer
  • Most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionising radiation.
  • The mean age of presentation is 3rd to 4th decade and is more common in women than men. Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.
  • It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:
  • Branching papillae
  • Follicles with fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes:
  • Optically clear: ground glass or Orphan Anne nuclei
  • Pseudo-inclusions
  • Nuclear grooves

Lymph node mets are common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a  cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis: lung> liver > bone> brain.

Has excellent prognosis with a 10 year survival rate.

 

Reference: Schwartz’s principles of surgery 10th edition page 1647

Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition pg 907

questions.text: A 40 year old female presented with malaise, fever, painful neck swelling. She had recently recovered from an episode of URTI. Lab reports show elevated ESR, and elevated T4 levels. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. NSAIDs

  • The given scenario is suggestive of De Quervain’s thyroiditis for which NSAIDs is the DOC. Here, T3 and T4 may be raised because of the release of preformed hormones from the destructed follicles.
  • Dequevrain’s thyroiditis (sub acute or viral thyroiditis) is a granulomatous enlargement of the thyroid gland, usually following a viral infection. It is an inflammatory condition and not an infection as the thyroid gland is inherently resistant to infection due to the extensive blood supply and lymphatics, high iodide content and fibrous capsule.

This disease predominantly occurs in women between 30-40 years. The condition is self limiting and management is symptomatic, ie. aspirin and other NSAIDs. Steroids may be indicated in severe painful cases.

 

Reference: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 27th edition, page 822

questions.text: A patient presents with a Thy3 lesion on FNAC. He was posted for hemithyroidectomy. HPE shows the following findings. What is your next step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Perform a total thyroidectomy

Capsular invasion seen in image confirms follicular carcinoma, hence total thyroidectomy to be done.

As FNAC shows Thy3 lesion, which is a follicular neoplasm, the frozen section of the excised specimen has to be evaluated. The presence of vascular invasion confirms follicular carcinoma.

Surgical management of differentiated thyroid cancers (DTCS) are as follows:

Reference: schwartz’s principles of surgery 11th edition page number 1651

choices.text: Ectopic thyroid in anterior sternocleidomastoid muscle

questions.text: Which of these represents lateral aberrant thyroid?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Level VI cervical node

“There is an extensive lymphatic network within and around the gland. Although some lymph channels pass directly to the deep cervical nodes, the subcapsular plexus drains principally to the central compartment juxta thyroid – ‘Delphian’ and paratracheal nodes and nodes on the superior and inferior thyroid veins (level VI) – and from there to the deep cervical (levels II, III, IV and V) and mediastinal groups of nodes (level VII)”.

 

Reference: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 850.

choices.text: Emergency cricothyrotomy
Shift to OT and remove sutures of wound
Needle thoracotomy in triangle of safety

questions.text: After total thyroidectomy, in post-operative recovery room, patient experienced acute breathlessness and cyanosis. His O2 saturation dropped to 85%. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Shift to OT and remove sutures of wound 

  • “Haemorrhage is the most frequent life-threatening complication of thyroidectomy. Around 1 in 50 patients will develop a haematoma, and in almost all cases this will develop in the first 24 hours. If an arterial bleed occurs, the tension in the central compartment pressure can rise until it exceeds venous pressure. Venous oedema of the larynx can then develop and cause airway obstruction, leading to death.
  • If a haematoma develops, clinical staff should know to remove skin sutures in order to release some pressure and seek senior advice immediately. Endotracheal intubation should be used to secure the airway while the haematoma is evacuated and the bleeding point controlled.” 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 865.

choices.text: Ligation of ITA away from the gland
Ligation of STA away from the gland
Ligation of ITA close to the gland
Ligation of STA close to the gland

questions.text: Which of these manoeuvres will prevent post op hypoparathyroidism in thyroidectomy (STA= Superior thyroid artery, ITA= Inferior thyroid artery)?
questions.solution:
Ans: C Ligation of ITA close to the gland

 

Truncal ligation of the inferior thyroid artery away from the gland can lead to hypoparathyroidsm due to ischemia. Both superior and inferior parathyroid glands receive their blood supply from ITA which arises from the subclavian arteries. Hence, during thyroidectomy, only the capsular branches closer to the thyroid gland should be ligated. 

 

Sometimes the parathyroid glands may have variable blood supply from thyroid-ima artery.

 

Reference: Gray’s anatomy: the anatomical basis of clinical practice , 41st edition, page 618 


Schwartz’s principle of surgery 10th edition, pages 1553-1554

choices.text: Indirect laryngoscopy for vocal palsy
Serum TSH, free T3 and T4 level

questions.text: 2 days post total thyroidectomy, patient complains of peri-oral tingling. What would be the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Serum calcium level 

  • “This is due to removal of the parathyroid glands or infarction through damage to the parathyroid end arteries; often both factors occur together. Vascular injury is probably far more important than inadvertent removal.
  • The incidence of permanent hypoparathyroidism should be less than 1% and most cases present dramatically 2–5 days after operation; very rarely, the onset is delayed for 2–3 weeks or a patient with marked hypocalcaemia may be asymptomatic. The complication is limited to total thyroidectomy, as when lobectomy is performed the contralateral parathyroid glands are sufficient to maintain calcium levels.
  • In particular, total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection places the parathyroid glands and their vascular supply at great risk and should only be performed when there is evidence of metastatic disease or high risk of occult disease in the regional lymph nodes.” 
  • For mild hypocalcemia, oral calcium and severe hypocalcemia, intravenous Calcium gluconate are supplemented. 

 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg. 866.

choices.text: Local invasion of surrounding structures

questions.text: Sudden rapid enlargement of a pre- existent thyroid swelling was noticed in a 75 year old woman. She now has difficulty swallowing and talking. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Anaplastic thyroid cancer

Anaplastic carcinoma is the most aggressive thyroid carcinoma with a poor prognosis. It usually occurs in elderly women above the age of 65 years and most often causes dysphagia.

Clinical features:

  • Rapidly enlarging neck mass
  • Dysphagia
  • Cervical tenderness
  • History of untreated DTC
  • Hoarseness of voice and tracheal obstruction

Diagnosis: FNAC.

Management:

  •  If metastasis is absent: total thyroidectomy + LN dissection
  • If metastasis is  present : palliative care with chemotherapy and radiotherapy

If tracheal obstruction : isthmusectomy to relieve tracheal obstruction

 

Reference: Bailey and love 27th edition, page 820

Schwartz’s principles of surgery 10th edition page 1550

Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition pg 910

questions.text: External low dose neck radiation predisposes to which kind of cancer most commonly?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Papillary carcinoma of thyroid.

History of low dose RT therapy to the head and neck for acne and tonsillitis and a cold nodule on RAI uptake scan are suggestive of papillary carcinoma.

The great majority of thyroid cancers have no known aetiological factor. The most important identifiable aetiological factor in differentiated thyroid carcinoma (particularly papillary) is irradiation of the thyroid under 5 years of age.

 

Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Edition: page 867

choices.text: It has a much poorer prognosis compared to follicular thyroid cancer
The investigation of choice for its diagnosis is FNAC
They are often bilateral and multifocal
Total thyroidectomy is the surgery of choice

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false with respect to the cancer shown in the below histopathological slide?
questions.solution:
Ans: B.  The investigation of choice for its diagnosis is FNAC

The above clinical picture is that of a Hurthle cell follicular carcinoma. Hurthle cell carcinoma is a variant of follicular cell carcinoma.

  • It has a poorer prognosis compared to follicular carcinomas as they are more likely to metastasize.
  • They are often bilateral and multifocal.
  • The HPE slide shows predominance of oxyphil/Hurthle/Askanazy cells containing abundant mitochondria.

They cannot be diagnosed on FNAC due to capsular and vascular invasion.

Surgical management is as follows:

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 868-869

questions.text: A doctor uses this method to palpate the midline swelling in the neck. Choose the correct option.
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Crile’s method

The following image depicts Crile’s method of palpation. Here, the patient is asked to swallow, while the examiner palpates the gland with the thumb. This method is sensitive in detecting a slight enlargement of the thyroid gland or small nodules.

Other methods:

  1. Lahey’s method: the lobes of the gland are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the lobe laterally with the left hand and the lobe is palpated using the right hand.
  2. Pizillo method: employed only in patients with short necks, usually in obese patients
  3. Kocher’s method: done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.

 

 

Ref: S. Das A manual on clinical surgery. Pg 378-380

choices.text: Central part of hyoid bone and thyroglossal tract
Thyroglossal tract and part of thyroid
Thyroglossal tract and associated cervical lymph nodes

questions.text: A child with a midline swelling in the neck, has to undergo a sistrunk procedure. Along with en bloc cystectomy, what other structures will the surgeon resect?
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Central part of hyoid bone and thyroglossal tract

Sistrunk operation involves en bloc cystectomy with excision of the entire thyroglossal tract till the base of the tongue along with the central hyoid bone.  It is the procedure of choice for the surgical management of thyroglossal cysts. Aim of surgery is to prevent recurrence and malignant transformation.

The most common malignancy in a thyroglossal cyst is papillary carcinoma. In such cases, sistrunk operation with total thyroidectomy is done.

 

Reference: Schwartz’s principles of surgery 10th edition page no 1522

choices.text: Oil of evening primrose

questions.text: All of these are components in management of cyclical mastalgia in women suffering from ANDI breast except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lumpectomy

 

Option D:

 

Lumpectomy is a surgical procedure to remove a breast lump and is not typically indicated for the management of mastalgia, which is usually treated medically.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oil of Evening Primrose: Evening primrose oil is rich in gamma-linolenic acid and is used as a dietary supplement to manage the symptoms of cyclical mastalgia.

 

Option B. Danazol: Danazol is a synthetic steroid that alters the hormonal milieu and is often used in the treatment of severe mastalgia. It's an effective, though less commonly used treatment due to its side effect profile.

 

Option C. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator used in the management of breast pain, particularly when it's severe or resistant to other treatments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For women suffering from cyclical mastalgia due to ANDI (aberrations of normal development and involution), management typically includes supportive measures and medications such as evening primrose oil, tamoxifen, or danazol. Lumpectomy is not a component of managing cyclical mastalgia as it is a surgical intervention reserved for the removal of lumps with potential or confirmed malignancy.

 

Management of Mastalgia:

 

  • Reassure adequate support
  • Tight sports brassiere during the day
  • Use a VAS breast pain chart to record severity
  • Consider medication
    • Flax seeds or Oil of evening primrose
    • Topical NSAID cream (diclofenac or piroxicam)- Useful in mild to moderate mastalgia
    • Consider systemic medication if pain score >3 on a VAS of 0-10
    • Tamoxifen 10 mg daily For 3–6 months
    • Danazol 50–300 mg daily For 3–6 months
    • Meloxifene 30 mg twice For 3–6 months used in both cyclical a week and non-cyclical mastalgia and for treating nodularity
    • LHRH agonist of Short duration: use for 3 months with anti estrogen: recalcitrant pain not relieved by the tamoxifen or raloxifene.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th E. table 58.2

choices.text: Stop taking OCP
DO mammography annually
Genetic counseling & BRCA testing
Immediate prophylactic mastectomy

questions.text: A 37-year-old unmarried female, nulliparous having regular sexual intercourse, on OCPs since last 3 years, gives the history that her mother had carcinoma breast at 50 years of age and sister had ovarian cancer at 40 years of age. What will you advise as the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Genetic counseling and BRCA testing

 

Option C:

 

Genetic Counseling & BRCA Testing Given her family history of breast and ovarian cancer, genetic counseling and BRCA testing are indicated. This will help to determine her risk for developing these cancers and guide appropriate surveillance and preventive strategies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Stop taking OCP: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) have been associated with a slightly increased risk of breast cancer, but they also offer protective effects against ovarian cancer. The decision to stop OCPs should be individualized based on a detailed risk assessment.

 

Option B. Do Mammography Annually: While annual mammography is important for breast cancer screening, starting annual mammograms at 37 without other indications might not be necessary, and it does not address her genetic risk.

 

Option D. Immediate Prophylactic Mastectomy: Prophylactic mastectomy may be considered for those with a confirmed high genetic risk (BRCA positive), but it is not the immediate next step before genetic risk is assessed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with a family history of breast and ovarian cancer, the next step is genetic counseling and BRCA testing to assess hereditary cancer risk and guide further preventive measures, rather than immediate prophylactic surgery or alteration of contraceptive practices.

 

Indications for genetic risk evaluation

 

  • An individual at any age with a known pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant in a cancer susceptibility gene within the family
  • Breast cancer diagnosed age ≤50 years
  • TNBC diagnosed age ≤60 years
  • Two breast cancer primaries
  • Breast cancer at any age with one or more relative with breast cancer diagnosed ≤50 years, invasive ovarian cancer, male breast cancer, pancreatic cancer, high-grade or metastatic prostate cancer
  • Breast cancer at any age with two or more affected relatives
  • Male breast cancer

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Summary box 58.5

choices.text: Imprint cytology
Sentinel LN biopsy
Fine-needle aspiration cytology
Tru Cut biopsy

questions.text: Which of the following histopathological modalities is the best to confirm the diagnosis of breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tru Cut biopsy

 

Option D:

 

Tru Cut/core-needle biopsy is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis of breast carcinoma. If it is inconclusive, excisional biopsy can be done.

 

Tru cut needle biopsy:

 

  • A 14G-16 G needle is used.
  • It permits the analysis of breast tissue architecture.
  • The advantages include a low complication rate, minimal scarring, and a lower cost as compared to excisional breast biopsy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A (Imprint Cytology): This technique involves pressing a tissue sample onto a glass slide to transfer cells, which are then stained and examined under a microscope. While it can provide rapid results, it is not as definitive as a core-needle biopsy because it does not preserve tissue architecture.

 

Option B (Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy): This procedure is used to determine the spread of breast cancer by examining the first lymph node(s) to which cancer cells are likely to spread from the primary tumor. It is not used for the initial diagnosis of breast cancer.

 

Option C (Fine-Needle Aspiration Cytology - FNAC): FNAC uses a thin needle to extract cells from a breast lump. It is less invasive than a core biopsy and can quickly suggest a diagnosis, but it may not be as definitive, particularly for distinguishing between in situ and invasive carcinomas.

 

  • Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a cytological investigation done using a 22-30G needle and is not the investigation of choice. FNAC cannot determine if a tumor is invasive or in situ. It is, however, the initial investigation in many cases.
  • Image-guided biopsy is used only in the case of non-palpable lesions.

 

Ref: Schwartz principle of surgery -9th edition page no 529, Bailey 28th Ed pg 918.

questions.text: Choose the radiographic modality that you will use to assess a patient’s breast containing silicone implants:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MRI

 

Option C:

 

MRI is the preferred imaging modality for evaluating the integrity of breast implants and for assessing the breast tissue in women with implants. It is more sensitive and provides a detailed image without the interference of the implant material.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mammography: While mammography is the standard imaging modality for breast cancer screening, it has limitations in evaluating breasts with silicone implants, as the implants can obscure visualization of the breast tissue.

 

Option B (USG): Ultrasound may help in evaluating certain areas of the breast and can be useful in distinguishing between fluid-filled cysts and solid masses, but it does not provide as comprehensive an assessment as MRI, especially in the presence of implants.

 

Option D (CT):Computed tomography (CT) is not typically used for routine breast imaging due to its lower sensitivity for detecting small breast cancers and because it exposes the patient to a higher dose of radiation compared to mammography.

 

Educational Objective

 

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the best imaging modality for the breasts of women with implants.

 

MRI of the breast is also used in:

 

  • Screening of individuals with a positive family history/high risk of breast cancer.
  • Assessing loco-regional spread (multifocality and multicentricity) of carcinoma
  • Differentiating scar form recurrence in women who have received breast conservation therapy.

 

Ref: Bailey and love’s short practice of surgery -28th edition page no 916-917

choices.text: Annual mammogram
Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months
Follow-up with tumor markers once in 6 months
Yearly bone scans

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman underwent treatment for breast cancer of 1.2 x 1 cm with positive axillary nodes. She completed radiotherapy and chemotherapy and is now receiving tamoxifen. Which investigation will you use for follow-up in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Annual mammogram

 

Option A:

 

The follow-up of breast cancer patients after treatment is crucial for early detection of recurrence and monitoring for any complications of treatment.

 

Annual Mammogram an annual mammogram is the standard follow-up investigation for breast cancer patients. It is used to monitor the treated breast and the contralateral breast for any new findings suggestive of recurrence or a new primary breast cancer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Regular Checking of Liver Function Tests (LFTs) Once in 6 Months. Routine liver function tests are not standard in the follow-up of breast cancer patients unless there are specific clinical indications or if the patient is experiencing symptoms suggestive of metastatic disease or complications related to systemic therapies.

 

Option C: Follow-up with Tumor Markers Once in 6 Months The use of tumor markers for routine follow-up in asymptomatic patients after primary treatment for breast cancer is not recommended. They have not been shown to provide a survival benefit in this setting.

 

Option D: Yearly Bone Scans Routine bone scans are not indicated for follow-up in asymptomatic breast cancer patients after primary treatment. They are reserved for patients with symptoms or clinical findings that suggest bone metastasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follow-up of patients after treatment of breast cancer consists of routine physical examination once in 3 months for a year and annual mammogram.

 

Mammography is the only imaging modality necessary for follow-up after breast cancer surgery. There is currently no role for tumor markers, serum investigations, or any other imaging studies like bone scan in follow-up.

 

Guidelines for follow-up:

 

Physical examination:

 

  • For the first 2 years: once every 3 to 6 months
  • For 3-5 years: once every 6 to 12 months after 5 years: Annually

 

Mammography:

 

  • Initially, 6 months after surgery
  • Thereafter, annually.

 

Ref: Bailey & Love’s short practice of surgery 27th edition Pg 879

choices.text: A history of smoking
A history of recent breastfeeding
A history of hormonal contraceptive use
A history of recent trauma

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with a chief complaint of persistent breast discomfort. On examination, there is localized tenderness, erythema, and a palpable breast lump. Nipple shows slit like retraction with fish mouth appearance. Which of the following findings is most likely risk factor in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A history of smoking

 

Option A:

 

Given scenario of tenderness, lump and slit like nipple retraction is suggestive of duct ectasia/chronic periductal mastitis which is commonly associated with smoking.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Breast feeding is linked to mastitis or breast abscess

 

Option C: Hormonal contraceptive are associated with breast carcinoma, although the risk is small

 

Option D: Recent trauma or hematoma may lead to traumatic fat necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duct ectasia, characterized by the dilation of lactiferous ducts and periductal inflammation, is the most common cause of greenish nipple discharge in the non-lactating breast, particularly in women above 50 years of age.

 

Duct ectasia (periductal mastitis) involves dilatation of multiple ducts, which is often associated with periductal inflammation.

 

  • Most common age group affected: above 50 years.
  • Most common presenting feature: nipple discharge

 

 

  • The patient presents with central non-cyclical pain, pus discharge from the nipple and a subareolar tender mass/ abscess or mammary duct fistula.
  • The examination reveals a tender, firm subareolar lump or abscess, purulent nipple discharge, thickened tender major milk ducts and a transverse slit-like nipple retraction looking like a fish’s mouth
  • Ultrasonography shows thickened major milk ducts with surrounding inflammation or abscess. A lump should be biopsied under ultrasound guidance to confirm the diagnosis.
  • The treatment for duct ectasia is Hadfield’s operation, which refers to the cone excision of the major duct system or sub areolar resection. All lactiferous ducts under the nipple are removed.
  • This procedure is performed when the duct of origin for the nipple bleeding is uncertain or when there is bleeding or discharge from multiple ducts.
  • If a single duct is involved, then microdochectomy is the treatment of choice.

 

Remember:

 

  • The most common cause of blood-stained discharge from a single duct is duct papilloma.
  • The most common cause of blood-stained discharge from multiple ducts is duct carcinoma.
  • The most common cause of serous discharge from the breast is fibrocystic disease of the breast.
  • Single duct single breast serous or sanguineous (4S) nipple discharge is considered pathological

 

Ref: Bailey and love’s short practice of surgery -27th edition page no 864, 867. 28th Ed. Pg 927.

choices.text: Most commonly felt in the calf muscles
Day to day distance is variable
Relived after getting out of bed

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker is diagnosed with peripheral vascular disease. Identify the true statement about intermittent claudication: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Most commonly felt in the calf muscles

 

Most commonly felt in the calf muscles: Correct. Intermittent claudication most commonly affects the calf muscles because the disease often affects the arteries supplying the lower limbs, usually the superficial femoral artery (70% of cases). Patients describe it as a cramping or aching sensation that occurs with walking or exertion and is relieved with rest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Felt at rest: Incorrect. Intermittent claudication is typically brought on by physical activity and relieved by rest. It occurs due to inadequate blood flow to the muscles during exertion.

 

Option C. Day to day distance is variable: Incorrect. While the severity of peripheral artery disease can change over time (especially without treatment), typically, the distance a person can walk before symptoms begin is fairly consistent, especially in the early stages of the disease.

 

Option D. Relieved after getting out of bed: Incorrect. Intermittent claudication pain is typically relieved after a few minutes of rest and doesn't specifically correlate with getting out of bed. The pain usually occurs during physical activities, such as walking, and subsides with rest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intermittent claudication is most commonly felt in the calf muscles due to the high prevalence of peripheral artery disease affecting the arteries that supply the lower limbs. This condition is typically brought on by physical activity and relieved by rest.

choices.text: On doppler, “monophasic flow” implies normal flow
Rest pain is seen at ABPI < 0.5
0.1 decrease in ABPI leads 10% increase in mortality
Toe pressure is more reliable of ischemia in patients with diabetes

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about peripheral vascular disease:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) On doppler, “monophasic flow” implies normal flow

 

In peripheral vascular disease (PVD), understanding Doppler findings and assessment measures is crucial:

 

  • On Doppler, “monophasic flow” implies normal flow: Incorrect. Normal arterial flow in the peripheral arteries is triphasic, indicating good vascular compliance and normal resistance. Monophasic flow is abnormal and indicates significant arterial disease with poor distal blood flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rest pain is seen at ABPI < 0.5: Correct. Rest pain in PVD patients typically occurs when the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) is less than 0.5, indicating severe ischemia.

 

Option C. 0.1 decrease in ABPI leads to a 10% increase in mortality: Correct. A decrease in ABPI is associated with increased cardiovascular mortality risk.

 

Option D. Toe pressure is more reliable for detecting ischemia in patients with diabetes: Correct. In diabetic patients, calcification of the arteries can make ABPI measurements unreliable. Toe pressure or the toe-brachial pressure index is often more accurate in assessing the severity of ischemia in these patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monophasic flow on Doppler is an indicator of significant arterial disease, not normal flow. Additionally, understand the importance of using toe pressure in diabetic patients for a more accurate assessment of ischemia, as ABPI can be unreliable due to calcified arteries.

 

ARTERIAL DOPPLER

 

  • Duplex scan= USG (B mode) + Doppler
  • Normal flow- Triphasic-> bi-> Mono-> absent
  • ABPI- <0.9 (occlusion), <0.5 (rest pain), <0.3 (CLI)
  • 0.1 fall in ABPI-> 10% increase in CV event
  • TBI < 0.6 in diabetes is more significant marker
